computer.builtInGames: 3.5'' FDD and 2.5'' IDE hard disk (44, 65 or 80 MB) depending models.
computer.colors: Two modes : 16 / 15 bit with True color mode or 262144 with paletted mode
computer.description:
The Atari Falcon 030 is the successor of the Atari 520 STe and the Atari TT 30.
It keeps some features these machines : The graphic modes (320 x 200 / 16 colors, 640 x 200 / 4 colors, 640 x 400 / 2 colors, 320 x 480 / 256 colors and 640 x 480 / 16 colors) and the sound chips (the old Yamaha PSG and the two 8 bits PCM channels of the STe).
Two new graphic modes have been added : a "small" 256 colors SVGA (640 x 480) and a true color VGA mode (32768 / 65535 colors in 320 x 480). Also when running on a TV, the resolutions are different: True Color mode is 640x480 in PAL and 640x400 in NTSC. The other TV resolutions also have a difference of vertical resolution between PAL and NTSC: 200 or 400 lines in NTSC, 240 or 480 in PAL.
New interfaces were added too : an ADC 16bit 50 KHz and a DSP I/O port. The videochip has also genlocking features.
The Falcon was sold with the single-task TOS operating system in ROM (4.04). It is the old Atari ST TOS with new functions to handle the DSP and the new graphic modes. The GUI was slightly enhanced with colored icons and 3D windows. Hopefully a multi-task TOS - MultiTOS) was also delivered on disks. This multitasking system uses the MiNT kernel and an enhanced GUI. MiNT (which stands for MiNT is NOT TOS) is a multitasking Operating System with lot of Unix features. It was initially done by Eric Smith. It was bought later by Atari and became then "MiNT is NOW TOS). Atari planned first to put it in ROM, but it was not finished and was shipped on disks. _______________________

emulator.description: Hatari is an Atari ST emulator for Linux, BSD, BeOS, Mac OS X and other systems that are supported by the SDL library. More precisely, Hatari is an adaption of the WinSTon source code to the SDL library.
emulator.name: Hatari

computer.graphics: ST Modes, TT Modes, VGA (640 x 480), True Color.

item.description: 170Mb Quantum hard-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;170MB QUANTUM HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This unit has an ICD Host Adapter.<
Atari Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote>This hard-drive has a 30Mb capacity.<

Inside the Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE THE MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seagate MFM 30 MB hard-disk Type ST-238<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(3)</b> Logical board<br> <b>(4)</b> Power and disk access LED's<br><

Atari universal modem||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI UNIVERSAL MODEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SX212 modem was one of the rare Atari peripherals that could be used with all the Atari computers range, from the 400/800 series up to the Falcon. It had both the Atari I/O ports for the 8-bit systems and a standard RS-232 connector for ST's<br><br> It was a 300/1200 baud modem compatible with the well-known Hayes 'AT' commands.<br> Cable and software was sold separately, depending of the computer used. <

SML-804|||Laser printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SML-804</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Laser printer</strong><br><blockquote>The SLM-804 was actually a Kyocera F1000 printer but without neither on-board processor and memory nor buttons other than the on/off switch. It was first delivered with the Mega ST but could be connected on all of the ST series computers through a dedicated interface box.<br> The printer used the processing power and the RAM memory of the ST computer for printing at 8 pages per minute and 300 DPI. The paper tray held 250 sheets.<

SMLC-804|||Laser printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SMLC-804</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Laser printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface allowed the SML-804 printer to be connected to any Atari ST holding at least 1 MB RAM.<

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;NICE PILLOW !</strong></font><br><blockquote>My cat, Praline, is using my Atari Falcon 030 as a pillow. It seems to be really comfortable !<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;CASE SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Left side<br><br> <b>(1)</b> MIDI In<br> <b>(2)</b> MIDI Out<br> <b>(3)</b> ROM cartridge connector<br> <b>(4)</b> 2 x joystick plugs<br><br> Right side<br><br> <b>(5)</b> Floppy-disc drive <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Midi In/Out DIN plugs<br> <b>(2)</b> Reset switch<br> <b>(3)</b> Lan MiniDIN plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Modem/Serial DB9 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Printer/Parallel DB25 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> IDE bus connector (hard-disk)<br> <b>(7)</b> Video signals generator chip called VIDEL<br> <b>(8)</b> RF modulator and TV aerial output chinch plug<br> <b>(9)</b> RGB monitor DB 19 connector<br> <b>(10)</b> SCSI controller chip<br> <b>(11)</b> SCSI connector<br> <b>(12)</b> Microphone / Headphone jacks<br> <b>(13)</b> DSP connector<br> <b>(14)</b> CODEC Chip<br> <b>(15)</b> 56K DSP (Digital Signal Processing) chip<br> <b>(16)</b> 64 KB DSP SRAM chips<br> <b>(17)</b> Direct Memory Access chip<br> <b>(18)</b> Floppy disc drive cables (data and power)<br> <b>(19)</b> fan<br> <b>(20)</b> BIOS and GEM ROM<br> <b>(21)</b> Memory expansion connectors<br> <b>(22)</b> COMBEL chip (MMU + GLUE + Blitter)<br> <b>(23)</b> Motorola 68030 microprocessor<br> <b>(24)</b> 'Direct Processor' expansion connector<br> <b>(25)</b> Joystick connectors<br> <b>(26)</b> Motorola Math coprocessor socket<br> <b>(27)</b> Multi-Function Peripheral 68901 chip. Performs a 8-bit parallel port, a built-in serial interface, timers and interrupts.<br> <b>(28)</b> ROM cartridges connector<
